sen.j: 御内書（ごないしょ）は、室町幕府の征夷大将軍が発給した私的な書状の形式を取った公文書。
sen.e: Gonaisho is an official document using the style of private letter that was issued by seii taishogun (literally, great general who subdues barbarians) of Muromachi bakufu.

Gonaisho was an official document written in the style of a private letter that was issued by the Seii Taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: capitalized "Seii Taishogun"; added description of bakufu to follow the word list; fixed grammar
sen.e: Gonaisho was an official document written in the style of a private letter that was issued by the Seii Taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 形式そのものは差出人が文面に表記される私信と同じものであるが、将軍自身による花押・署判（署名・捺印）が加えられていた。
sen.e: Although its style itself was same with a private letter whose sender's name is written in a text, kao (written seal mark) or shohan (signature/seal) by shogun himself was added to it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although a Gonaisho was written in the style of a private letter with the sender's name written in the text, a kao (written seal mark) or shohan (signature/seal) was added to the document by the shogun himself.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Although a Gonaisho was written in the style of a private letter with the sender's name written in the text, a kao (written seal mark) or shohan (signature/seal) was added to the document by the shogun himself.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのため、将軍個人の私的性の強い命令書でありながら、御教書に準じるものとして幕府の公式な命令書と同様の法的効力があった。
sen.e: As a result, it was deemed as quasi-migyosho (an official document informing people of the government decision) and had legal weight equivalent to bakufu' official order, though it was something like shogun's private order.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a result, these documents were deemed as a kind of Migyosho (an official document informing people of a government decision), and even though it was more of a private order made by the shogun, it had the legal weight equivalent to an official bakufu order.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally; capitalized "Migyosho"
sen.e: As a result, these documents were deemed as a kind of Migyosho (an official document informing people of a government decision), and even though it was more of a private order made by the shogun, it had the legal weight equivalent to an official bakufu order.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 主に、将軍の私的な用向を伝える書状として機能していた。
sen.e: Initially, it was issued mainly for the purpose of conveying shogun's private business.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was initially issued mainly for the purpose of conveying the private business of the shogun.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: It was initially issued mainly for the purpose of conveying the private business of the shogun.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、室町時代後半になると管領などが発給する御教書が減少するかわりに御内書が増大し、将軍の意思を直接通達する書状として公文書化する。
sen.e: In the late Muromachi period, however, the issuance of Gonaisho increased in place of migyosho, which was issued by kanrei (shogunal deputy), and its nature changed to a quasi-official document by which shogun directly informed people of his intention.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the late Muromachi period, however, Gonaisho were increasingly issued in place of Migyosho issued by kanrei (shogunal deputy), and its nature became more of a quasi-official document used by the shogun to directly inform people of his intentions.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: During the late Muromachi period, however, Gonaisho were increasingly issued in place of Migyosho issued by kanrei (shogunal deputy), and its nature became more of a quasi-official document used by the shogun to directly inform people of his intentions.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、江戸幕府も将軍の意思の伝達する文書として、御内書を継承した。
sen.e: The Edo bakufu succeeded gonaisho as a document informing people of shogun's intention.
The Edo bakufu inherited the Gonaisho as a document to inform people of the shogun's intentions.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: The Edo bakufu inherited the Gonaisho as a document to inform people of the shogun's intentions.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: なお、通常は側近である侍臣による副状が添付されるのが慣例であった。
sen.e: Under normal circumstances, gonaisho was issued together with an accompanying letter of courtier, shogun's close aide.
It was customary that, under normal circumstances, a Gonaisho was issued with an accompanying letter by an attendant who was a close aide to the shogun.
sen.cmt: changed "courtier" to "attendant"; added "It was customary that" for 慣例であった; fixed grammar
sen.e: It was customary that, under normal circumstances, a Gonaisho was issued with an accompanying letter by an attendant who was a close aide to the shogun.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 文型としては宛所（宛先）と書止めがそれぞれ「某とのへ・也」とより丁寧な表現の「某殿・也、状如件」の2形式が存在した。
sen.e: There were two kinds of documentary forms, namely the one which used respectful words in writing an addrssee/ ending word and the normal one, and these were separately used depending on addressee's court rank and social status.
sen.cmt: 「某とのへ・也」、「某殿・也、状如件」は、翻訳不可能のため、省略しております。/一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There were two kinds of documentary forms, more specifically one which used respectful words in writing the name of the addressee and ending the letter, and a normal letter which did not use respectful words. Each type of form was separately used depending on the court rank and social status of the addressee.
sen.cmt: split into two sentences to read more comfortably; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: There were two kinds of documentary forms, more specifically one which used respectful words in writing the name of the addressee and ending the letter, and a normal letter which did not use respectful words.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」扱いに。

sen.j: これらはそれぞれ、宛所の身分や社会的地位で使い分けていた。

sen.j: 五山の住持の任命状である公帖は御教書あるいは御内書として発給されている。
sen.e: Kojo, an official writ of appointment to the chief of gozan (five great Zen temples in Kyoto), was issued either as Migyosho or gonaisho.

sen.e: Kojo, an official written appointment to the chief of the gozan (five great Zen temples in Kyoto) was issued either as a Migyosho or Gonaisho.
